column2: BOILED STURGEON--II
column3: BOILED STURGEON-two

column2: Boil the fish in court bouillon and serve with Drawn-Butter Sauce.
column3: Boil the fish in court bouillon and serve with Drawn Butter Sauce.

column2: BROILED STURGEON STEAKS--I
column3: BROILED STURGEON STEAKS-I

column2: Parboil sturgeon steaks for fifteen minutes, drain, wipe dry, season with salt and pepper, and broil.
column3: Parboil sturgeon steaks for fifteen minutes, drain, wipe dry, season with salt and pepper, and broil.

column2: Serve with melted butter or Maitre d'Hotel Sauce.
column3: Serve with melted butter or Maitre d'Hotel Sauce.

column2: BROILED STURGEON STEAKS--II
column3: BROILED STURGEON STEAKS-two

column2: Skin and soak for an hour in cold salted [Page 402] water.
column3: Skin and soak for an hour in cold salted [Page four hundred two] water.

column2: Drain, wipe dry, and soak for an hour in a marinade of oil and vinegar.
column3: Drain, wipe dry, and soak for an hour in a marinade of oil and vinegar.

column2: Drain and broil.
column3: Drain and broil.

column2: Serve with melted butter and lemon-juice.
column3: Serve with melted butter and lemon juice.

column2: BROILED STURGEON STEAKS--III
column3: BROILED STURGEON STEAKS-three

column2: Skin the steaks and soak in cold, salted water for an hour, drain, season, and broil, basting with melted butter as required.
column3: Skin the steaks and soak in cold, salted water for an hour, drain, season, and broil, basting with melted butter as required.

column2: Season with melted butter and garnish with lemon quarters and parsley. Or, brown a tablespoonful of flour in butter, add half a cupful of cold water and cook until thick, stirring constantly.
column3: Season with melted butter and garnish with lemon quarters and parsley. Or, brown a tablespoonful of flour in butter, add half a cupful of cold water and cook until thick, stirring constantly.

column2: Season with salt, lemon-juice, and Worcestershire Sauce, or anchovy essence. Bring to the boil, pour over the fish, and serve.
column3: Season with salt, lemon juice, and Worcestershire Sauce, or anchovy essence. Bring to the boil, pour over the fish, and serve.

column2: FRIED STURGEON--I
column3: FRIED STURGEON-I

column2: Parboil slices of sturgeon in milk for fifteen minutes, drain, dip in beaten egg, then in seasoned flour, and fry brown in butter.
column3: Parboil slices of sturgeon in milk for fifteen minutes, drain, dip in beaten egg, then in seasoned flour, and fry brown in butter.

column2: FRIED STURGEON--II
column3: FRIED STURGEON-two

column2: Cut the fish into cutlets, dredge with flour, dip into egg and crumbs, and saute in a frying-pan.
column3: Cut the fish into cutlets, dredge with flour, dip into egg and crumbs, and saute in a frying pan.

column2: Drain off the fat, add a little flour and cook to a smooth paste.
column3: Drain off the fat, add a little flour and cook to a smooth paste.

column2: Add boiling water to make a sauce, and cook until thick, stirring constantly.
column3: Add boiling water to make a sauce, and cook until thick, stirring constantly.

column2: Season with grated onion, [Page 403] pepper and salt and sweet herbs.
column3: Season with grated onion, [Page four hundred three] pepper and salt and sweet herbs.

column2: Reheat the fish in the sauce, squeeze in the juice of half a lemon, and serve.
column3: Reheat the fish in the sauce, squeeze in the juice of half a lemon, and serve.

column2: FRIED STURGEON--III
column3: FRIED STURGEON-three

column2: Cut sturgeon steaks into small cutlets.
column3: Cut sturgeon steaks into small cutlets.

column2: Dip into egg and crumbs, fry in fat to cover, and serve with any preferred sauce.
column3: Dip into egg and crumbs, fry in fat to cover, and serve with any preferred sauce.

column2: BAKED STURGEON--I
column3: BAKED STURGEON-I

column2: Skin a large cut of sturgeon, parboil for fifteen minutes, drain, cover with a marinade of oil and vinegar, and let stand for an hour. Gash the surface deeply and fill the incision with a force meat of bread-crumbs and minced salt pork, seasoning with lemon-juice, pepper, and minced parsley, and adding enough melted butter to make smooth.
column3: Skin a large cut of sturgeon, parboil for fifteen minutes, drain, cover with a marinade of oil and vinegar, and let stand for an hour. Gash the surface deeply and fill the incision with a force meat of bread crumbs and minced salt pork, seasoning with lemon juice, pepper, and minced parsley, and adding enough melted butter to make smooth.

column2: Cover, add enough boiling water to keep from burning, and bake, basting frequently.
column3: Cover, add enough boiling water to keep from burning, and bake, basting frequently.

column2: BAKED STURGEON--II
column3: BAKED STURGEON-two

column2: Skin a large cut of sturgeon, parboil for fifteen minutes, drain, and cool.
column3: Skin a large cut of sturgeon, parboil for fifteen minutes, drain, and cool.

column2: Rub with a marinade of oil and vinegar, cover, and bake with enough water to keep from burning.
column3: Rub with a marinade of oil and vinegar, cover, and bake with enough water to keep from burning.

column2: Serve with Caper Sauce.
column3: Serve with Caper Sauce.

column2: [Page 404] BAKED STURGEON--III
column3: [Page four hundred four] BAKED STURGEON-three

column2: Skin a six-pound cut of sturgeon and parboil for twenty minutes. Drain and put into a baking-pan on a layer of thinly sliced bacon. Add enough boiling water to keep from burning, and bake until done, basting often.
column3: Skin a six pound cut of sturgeon and parboil for twenty minutes. Drain and put into a baking pan on a layer of thinly sliced bacon. Add enough boiling water to keep from burning, and bake until done, basting often.

column2: BAKED STURGEON--IV
column3: BAKED STURGEON-i v

column2: Skin a six-pound cut of sturgeon, soak in salted water for an hour, drain, and parboil in fresh water.
column3: Skin a six pound cut of sturgeon, soak in salted water for an hour, drain, and parboil in fresh water.

column2: Make a stuffing of bread-crumbs, chopped salt pork, sweet herbs, and enough melted butter to make a smooth paste.
column3: Make a stuffing of bread crumbs, chopped salt pork, sweet herbs, and enough melted butter to make a smooth paste.

column2: Score the upper-side of the fish deeply and fill the gashes with the stuffing.
column3: Score the upper side of the fish deeply and fill the gashes with the stuffing.

column2: Put in a buttered baking-pan with enough water to keep from burning, and bake for an hour, basting as required.
column3: Put in a buttered baking pan with enough water to keep from burning, and bake for an hour, basting as required.

column2: Serve with Drawn-Butter Sauce, seasoned with capers and catsup.
column3: Serve with Drawn Butter Sauce, seasoned with capers and catsup.

column2: BAKED STURGEON--V
column3: BAKED STURGEON-V

column2: Cover a buttered baking-pan with thin slices of salt pork.
column3: Cover a buttered baking pan with thin slices of salt pork.

column2: Sprinkle with chopped carrot, turnip, and onion, and lay a thick cut of sturgeon upon it.
column3: Sprinkle with chopped carrot, turnip, and onion, and lay a thick cut of sturgeon upon it.

column2: Season the fish with salt, pepper, and lemon-juice, and cover with thin slices of pork.
column3: Season the fish with salt, pepper, and lemon juice, and cover with thin slices of pork.

column2: Cook for ten minutes, [Page 405] then add one cupful of boiling water, and cook slowly, basting as required.
column3: Cook for ten minutes, [Page four hundred five] then add one cupful of boiling water, and cook slowly, basting as required.

column2: Dredge with seasoned flour after each basting, and add more boiling water if necessary.
column3: Dredge with seasoned flour after each basting, and add more boiling water if necessary.

column2: After the fish has cooked for an hour, remove the pork, and drop it into the pan.
column3: After the fish has cooked for an hour, remove the pork, and drop it into the pan.

column2: Pour a wineglassful of Sherry over the fish, spread with butter, and dredge thickly with flour.
column3: Pour a wineglassful of Sherry over the fish, spread with butter, and dredge thickly with flour.

column2: Bake until the fish is a rich brown color.
column3: Bake until the fish is a rich brown color.

column2: Take out the pork and add enough boiling water to the liquid in the pan to make the required quantity of sauce.
column3: Take out the pork and add enough boiling water to the liquid in the pan to make the required quantity of sauce.

column2: Thicken with butter and flour cooked together, strain, and serve with the fish.
column3: Thicken with butter and flour cooked together, strain, and serve with the fish.

column2: STURGEON A LA CARDINAL
column3: STURGEON A l a CARDINAL

column2: Clean two pounds of sturgeon, bind into shape with tape, and put it into a buttered saucepan with acidulated water to cover.
column3: Clean two pounds of sturgeon, bind into shape with tape, and put it into a buttered saucepan with acidulated water to cover.

column2: Add an onion, four cloves, a blade of mace, a sliced carrot, and a bunch of sweet herbs.
column3: Add an onion, four cloves, a blade of mace, a sliced carrot, and a bunch of sweet herbs.

column2: Simmer gently until the fish is done and serve with Lobster Sauce.
column3: Simmer gently until the fish is done and serve with Lobster Sauce.

column2: STURGEON A LA FRANCAISE
column3: STURGEON A l a FRANCAISE

column2: Skin and clean a five-pound cut of sturgeon, and tie into shape with strings.
column3: Skin and clean a five pound cut of sturgeon, and tie into shape with strings.

column2: Put into a buttered saucepan with sliced carrots and onions, a bunch of parsley, three blades of mace, three cloves [Page 406] of garlic, and salt and pepper to season.
column3: Put into a buttered saucepan with sliced carrots and onions, a bunch of parsley, three blades of mace, three cloves [Page four hundred six] of garlic, and salt and pepper to season.

column2: Add red wine and white stock in equal parts to cover.
column3: Add red wine and white stock in equal parts to cover.

column2: Simmer until done, drain, and keep warm.
column3: Simmer until done, drain, and keep warm.

column2: Take enough of the strained liquid to make a sauce, and thicken with butter and flour cooked together.
column3: Take enough of the strained liquid to make a sauce, and thicken with butter and flour cooked together.

column2: Take from the fire, add a tablespoonful of anchovy essence, a dash of paprika, two tablespoonfuls of butter, and the juice of a lemon.
column3: Take from the fire, add a tablespoonful of anchovy essence, a dash of paprika, two tablespoonfuls of butter, and the juice of a lemon.

column2: Pour over the fish and serve.
column3: Pour over the fish and serve.

column2: STURGEON A LA NORMANDY
column3: STURGEON A l a NORMANDY

column2: Remove the skin from a five-pound cut of sturgeon, cover with thin slices of salt pork, and tie into shape with a string.
column3: Remove the skin from a five pound cut of sturgeon, cover with thin slices of salt pork, and tie into shape with a string.

column2: Put into a saucepan with sliced vegetables, two tablespoonfuls of butter, one cupful of white wine, two cupfuls of white stock, a little oyster or mussel liquor, and salt and sweet herbs to season.
column3: Put into a saucepan with sliced vegetables, two tablespoonfuls of butter, one cupful of white wine, two cupfuls of white stock, a little oyster or mussel liquor, and salt and sweet herbs to season.

column2: Cover and cook slowly for an hour, basting with the liquid frequently. When done, drain the fish, and keep warm.
column3: Cover and cook slowly for an hour, basting with the liquid frequently. When done, drain the fish, and keep warm.

column2: Strain the liquid, skim off the fat, thicken with a tablespoonful each of butter and flour cooked together, take from the fire, add the yolks of four eggs beaten with the juice of a lemon, and two tablespoonfuls of butter in small bits.
column3: Strain the liquid, skim off the fat, thicken with a tablespoonful each of butter and flour cooked together, take from the fire, add the yolks of four eggs beaten with the juice of a lemon, and two tablespoonfuls of butter in small bits.

column2: Take the pork off the sturgeon, pour the sauce over, and serve.
column3: Take the pork off the sturgeon, pour the sauce over, and serve.
